overview.title: 0nVault Security System
overview.tagline: Military-grade encryption for AI orchestration credentials and configurations.
overview.description: 0nVault is a patent-pending encrypted container system that protects every layer of your AI orchestration stack. Seven semantic layers, multi-party escrow, tamper-proof seals, and secure transfer -- all in a single .0nv binary container.

features.title: Binary Container Format
features.description: The .0nv format is a compact binary container that bundles encrypted layers, signatures, metadata, and seals into a single portable file.

faq.a: 0nVault is a patent-pending encrypted container system designed specifically for AI orchestration. It protects credentials, workflows, configurations, and audit trails using military-grade encryption (AES-256-GCM) with Ed25519 digital signatures and SHA3-256 integrity verification.

faq.q: How does 0nVault differ from a password manager?
faq.a: Unlike password managers that store individual credentials, 0nVault encrypts entire orchestration contexts -- 7 semantic layers including workflows, MCP configs, site profiles, and AI brain states. It supports multi-party escrow, tamper-proof seals, and secure transfer with replay prevention.

The 0nVault specification and reference implementation are part of the 0nMCP ecosystem (MIT licensed). The patent-pending innovations (container format, semantic layers, escrow protocol) are protected under US Patent Application #63/990,046.

AES-256-GCM for symmetric encryption, Ed25519 for digital signatures, X25519 ECDH for key agreement in multi-party escrow, Argon2id for credential key derivation, and SHA3-256 for content-addressed integrity seals.

faq.q: Can I verify a container without decrypting it?
faq.a: Yes. The Seal of Truth uses SHA3-256 content hashing to produce a verification fingerprint. Anyone with the seal can verify the container has not been tampered with, without needing the decryption key.

faq.a: The .0nv format is a binary container that packages 7 encrypted semantic layers, digital signatures, integrity seals, and transfer logs into a single portable file. It starts with the magic bytes '0NV1' followed by versioned sections.

faq.q: How large is a typical .0nv container?
faq.a: A typical container with all 7 layers populated ranges from 2KB to 50KB depending on the complexity of your workflows and number of credentials. The binary format is significantly more compact than equivalent JSON.

While .0nv files are binary and not ideal for line-by-line diffs, they work well with Git LFS. Each container includes a version field and timestamp, and the Seal of Truth provides content-addressed identification.

faq.q: What happens if a .0nv file is corrupted?
faq.a: The Seal of Truth verification will immediately detect any corruption. AES-256-GCM authenticated encryption also provides per-layer integrity checking, so even partial corruption is detected before any data is returned.

layers.title: 7 Semantic Layers
layers.tagline: Independent encryption for every aspect of your AI orchestration stack.
layers.description: 0nVault organizes your AI orchestration context into 7 semantic layers. Each layer is encrypted independently with its own AES-256-GCM key, enabling granular access control in multi-party scenarios. Credentials receive double-encryption with Argon2id key derivation.

layers.name: Workflows
layers.description: Your .0n SWITCH files -- the orchestration logic that connects services, defines pipelines, and automates processes. Includes step definitions, conditions, transforms, and execution parameters.

layers.name: Credentials
layers.description: API keys, OAuth tokens, service passwords, and authentication secrets for all 26 connected services. Double-encrypted: first with Argon2id-derived key, then with the layer key.

layers.name: Environment Variables
layers.description: Runtime configuration values, feature flags, endpoint URLs, and deployment-specific settings. Separated from credentials for different access control needs.

layers.name: MCP Configurations
layers.description: AI platform configurations for Claude Desktop, Cursor, Windsurf, Gemini, Continue, Cline, and OpenAI. Includes server definitions, tool registrations, and platform-specific settings.

layers.name: Site Profiles
layers.description: Website and application configurations, domain settings, deployment targets, and environment mappings. Links orchestration contexts to specific deployments.

layers.name: AI Brain
layers.description: Trained context, prompt templates, model preferences, fine-tuning parameters, and AI behavior configurations. The intelligence layer that makes your orchestration context-aware.

layers.name: Audit Trail
layers.description: Immutable execution logs, access records, modification history, and compliance data. Append-only by design -- entries can be added but never modified or deleted.

escrow.title: Multi-Party Escrow
escrow.tagline: Share encrypted containers with granular per-layer access control.
escrow.description: 0nVault multi-party escrow uses X25519 Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman key agreement to enable up to 8 parties to share a single encrypted container. Each party receives access only to the layers they need, with cryptographic enforcement.

features.title: Per-Layer Access Matrix
features.description: Define exactly which layers each party can decrypt. A DevOps team member might access env_vars and site_profiles but not credentials or AI brain.

features.title: Key Agreement Without Key Sharing
features.description: X25519 ECDH derives shared secrets between party pairs without ever transmitting private keys. Each party generates their own keypair.

features.title: Revocable Access
features.description: Re-key individual layers to revoke access for specific parties without affecting other participants. The container is re-sealed with updated access controls.

features.title: Audit Visibility
features.description: The audit trail layer can be made visible to all parties regardless of other access controls, ensuring transparency and compliance.

faq.a: Each party generates an X25519 keypair. When creating a shared container, the owner performs ECDH key agreement with each party's public key to derive unique shared secrets. These secrets encrypt per-layer keys, so each party can only decrypt the layers they're authorized for.

faq.q: What is the maximum number of parties?
faq.a: Up to 8 parties can share a single .0nv container. This limit balances security (minimizing key material in the container) with practical team collaboration needs.

faq.q: Can I revoke a party's access?
faq.a: Yes. Re-key the affected layers with new AES-256-GCM keys and re-perform ECDH key agreement with the remaining authorized parties. The revoked party's derived keys will no longer decrypt the updated layers.
Yes. All escrow operations are logged in the audit trail layer. Access grants, revocations, key rotations, and container opens are recorded with timestamps and party identifiers.

seal_of_truth.title: Seal of Truth
seal_of_truth.description: The Seal of Truth is a SHA3-256 content-addressed integrity fingerprint embedded in every .0nv container. It allows anyone to verify that a container has not been tampered with, without needing the decryption key.

formula_explanation.description: Container header bytes including version, flags, and timestamp
Layer index with types, sizes, and encryption parameters
SHA3-256 hash of each encrypted layer, sorted by layer ID for deterministic ordering
All Ed25519 digital signatures from creator and escrow parties

properties.title: Content-Addressed
properties.description: The seal is derived from the container's actual content, not metadata. Two containers with identical content produce identical seals.

properties.title: Tamper-Evident
properties.description: Any modification to any byte in the container -- header, layers, signatures, or metadata -- produces a completely different seal.

properties.title: Public Verification
properties.description: Verification requires only the container file and the published seal. No decryption keys, no private information, no network access.

properties.title: Collision Resistant
properties.description: SHA3-256 provides 128-bit collision resistance. Finding two different containers that produce the same seal is computationally infeasible.

transfer.title: Secure Transfer Protocol
transfer.tagline: Cryptographic chain of custody for .0nv containers.
transfer.description: The 0nVault secure transfer protocol provides replay prevention, transfer ID tracking, and an immutable chain of custody for every container transfer. Each transfer is cryptographically signed and logged.

features.title: Transfer Registry
features.description: Every transfer is registered with a unique Transfer ID, sender signature, recipient public key, timestamp, and layer access grants. The registry is append-only.

features.title: Replay Prevention
features.description: Each transfer includes a nonce and timestamp. The recipient verifies the nonce has not been seen before and the timestamp is within an acceptable window, preventing replay attacks.

features.title: Transfer ID Tracking
features.description: A UUID v7 Transfer ID is generated for each transfer operation. This ID is embedded in the container's transfer log and can be used to trace the complete chain of custody.

features.title: Sender Verification
features.description: The sender signs the transfer with their Ed25519 private key. The recipient can verify the sender's identity using the published public key, ensuring transfers are not forged.

features.title: Layer Re-encryption
features.description: During transfer, layers are re-encrypted for the recipient using X25519 ECDH key agreement. The sender's copy remains encrypted with the original keys.

features.title: Immutable Transfer Log
features.description: The container's transfer log section is append-only. Each entry includes the Transfer ID, parties involved, layers transferred, and cryptographic proofs.
